newsitem.title: UK: NWE gas oil off on futures, low sulphur pressured.
newsitem.headline: NWE gas oil off on futures, low sulphur pressured.

text.p: NWE gas oil eased on Wednesday in line with falling benchmark IPE gas oil futures, ample supply and slack demand, traders said.
June IPE gas oil was $2.0 lower at $168.00 a tonne.
Heating oil premiums were static at around $1.0/$1.75 fob ARA for first half June delivery. Two lots of 1,000 tonnes traded at June IPE +$1.25 fob Rotterdam earlier.
Traders said a few players appeared to have taken advantage of the lower futures prices to cover a few shorts.
Low sulphur continued under pressure with differentials for first half June delivery barges at June IPE +$7.0/+$9.0 fob ARA.
A refiner picked up a small low sulphur barge for $8.50, but players said the number was on the high side. Few buyers were prepared to go above +$7.0.
"The trouble is that there is low sulphur material everywhere," said one trader.
Traders blamed the slump in low sulphur diesel prices on the arrival of arbitraged Algerian and Italian cargoes in the north in a generally slack market.
"German demand had been low recently," said one trader.
On cargoes, many players speculated about the intentions of a Wall Street trader.
That player picked up on Tuesday three cargoes of low sulphur material at June IPE +$6.0, $6.50 and %5.25 cif NWE for first half delivery.
Some thought the trader had been merely taking advantage of the competitive prices while others speculated the trader was looking to work the arbitrage to the Far East.
